entry.title: üî¥ Astrobiology ‚û§ Redox Diversity of Interstellar Compounds and Human Nutrients Reveals a Potentially Universal Chemical Constraint for Life
entry.summary: Compares redox classifications of interstellar molecules and human nutrients against PubChem chemical space, finding a shared prooxidant/proreductant/amphoteric balance that may reflect a universal chemical constraint relevant to life‚Äôs origins.
entry.content:
Abstract:
Comparative analysis of redox properties across three chemically distinct datasets‚Äîinterstellar compounds, human nutritional molecules, and >40 million substances in the PubChem database‚Äîreveals a striking and highly non-random pattern. Interstellar molecules and human nutrients exhibit nearly identical proportions of prooxidant, proreductant, and amphoteric species. In contrast, the PubChem chemical space is overwhelmingly dominated by amphoteric molecules [‚Ä¶] The post Redox Diversity of Interstellar Compounds and Human Nutrients Reveals a Potentially Universal Chemical Constraint for Life appeared first on Astrobiology .

Source Paper / DOIs Found:
  • [PubMed/NCBI] https://pubchem.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/

entry.title: üü† Astrobiology ‚û§ LIFE NASA RCN Seminar 6 January 2026
entry.summary: Seminar announcement featuring work on deconvolving ancient biomarker signals to better interpret early ecosystem composition and eukaryotic evolution, relevant to biosignature interpretation but not directly focused on abiogenesis.
entry.content:
Abstract:
Join the 2026 LIFE NASA RCN Seminar Series! This month‚Äôs speakers are Dr. Ilya Bobrovskiy and Dr. Tharika Liyanage. Time: January 6th, 8AM PDT/11AM EDTJOIN Title: Unmixing ancient biomarker signals to recover primary ecosystem composition. Dr. Ilya Bobrovskiy leads a research group at MARUM that seeks to deconvolve the early record of eukaryotic evolution using [‚Ä¶] The post LIFE NASA RCN Seminar 6 January 2026 appeared first on Astrobiology .

entry.title: üî¥ Astrobiology ‚û§ University Of Canterbury Team Led Study Of Interstellar Comet 3I/ATLAS
entry.summary: Reports on observations and characterization of interstellar comet 3I/ATLAS, a rare visitor that may inform astrobiology via constraints on the composition and evolution of small bodies formed in other planetary systems.
entry.content:
Abstract:
The comet 3I/ATLAS, discovered by an international team in July this year, is only the third interstellar object ever found in the history of astronomy. It is the first that is bright enough to be seen through amateur telescopes and is currently visible in the Northern Hemisphere. It will make its closest approach to Earth [‚Ä¶] The post University Of Canterbury Team Led Study Of Interstellar Comet 3I/ATLAS appeared first on Astrobiology .

entry.title: üî¥ Astrobiology ‚û§ HKUST Launches World‚Äôs First Deep-sea Multi-omics Resource Platform Empowering Global Research Into Biological Adaptation In Extreme Environments
entry.summary: Introduces a large deep-ocean multi-omics database (DOO) enabling comparative analyses of life in extreme marine environments, offering indirect value for origins-of-life and habitability analog studies rather than directly addressing prebiotic chemistry or abiogenesis.
entry.content:
Abstract:
The Hong Kong University of Science and Technology (HKUST), in collaboration with the Southern Marine Science and Engineering Guangdong Laboratory (Guangzhou), has launched the world‚Äôs first Deep Ocean Omics (DOO) database (https://DeepOceanOmics.org/). As the largest platform of its kind, DOO integrates and analyzes multi-omics data from organisms thriving in the ocean‚Äôs most extreme environments, alongside [‚Ä¶] The post HKUST Launches World‚Äôs First Deep-sea Multi-omics Resource Platform Empowering Global Research Into Biological Adaptation In Extreme Environments appeared first on Astrobiology .

entry.title: üü† Astrobiology ‚û§ Observational Evidence For A Possible Link Between PAH Emission And Dust Trap Locations In Protoplanetary Disks
entry.summary: Compares PAH emission strengths with ALMA dust-trap locations in protoplanetary disks, suggesting PAHs may freeze onto grains and be sequestered in dust traps‚Äîrelevant to disk organic chemistry but only indirectly to origins-of-life pathways.
entry.content:
Abstract:
Polycyclic Aromatic Hydrocarbons (PAHs) are commonly detected in protoplanetary disks, but it is unclear what causes the wide range of intensities across the samples. In this work, the measured PAH intensities of a range of disks are compared with ALMA dust continuum images, in order to test whether there is evidence that PAHs are frozen [‚Ä¶] The post Observational Evidence For A Possible Link Between PAH Emission And Dust Trap Locations In Protoplanetary Disks appeared first on Astrobiology .

Source Paper / DOIs Found:
  • [ArXiv Preprint] https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.06935
  • [DOI Link] https://doi.org/10.48550/arXiv.2511.06935

entry.title: üî¥ Astrobiology ‚û§ Performance Calibration of the Wavefront Sensor‚Äôs EMCCD Detector for the Cool Planets Imaging Coronagraph Aboard CSST
entry.summary: This paper characterizes and calibrates the EMCCD detector used in CSST‚Äôs coronagraph wavefront sensor, improving high-contrast exoplanet imaging capability but offering only indirect relevance to origins-of-life research.
entry.content:
Abstract:
The wavefront sensor (WFS), equipped with an electron-multiplying charge-coupled device (EMCCD) detector, is a critical component of the Cool Planets Imaging Coronagraph (CPI-C) on the Chinese Space Station Telescope (CSST). Precise calibration of the WFS‚Äôs EMCCD detector is essential to meet the stringent requirements for high-contrast exoplanet imaging. This study comprehensively characterizes key performance parameters [‚Ä¶] The post Performance Calibration of the Wavefront Sensor‚Äôs EMCCD Detector for the Cool Planets Imaging Coronagraph Aboard CSST appeared first on Astrobiology .

entry.title: üî¥ Astrobiology ‚û§ Understanding Protein Form And Function Better At TU Graz
entry.summary: A structural biology study aimed at improving understanding of protein 3D form‚Äìfunction relationships, broadly relevant to biomolecular evolution but not directly focused on origins-of-life mechanisms or prebiotic chemistry.
entry.content:
Abstract:
Proteins are among the most important building blocks of nature and play a central role in biological processes in all organisms. Accordingly, scientists are keen to understand them as precisely as possible. As polymers of different amino acids, proteins can have different 3-dimensional structures and various functions. However, it is often difficult to determine which [‚Ä¶] The post Understanding Protein Form And Function Better At TU Graz appeared first on Astrobiology .

entry.title: üî¥ Astrobiology ‚û§ Fungi From Chernobyl: Mycobiota Of The Inner Regions Of The Containment Structures Of The Damaged Nuclear Reactor
entry.summary: Survey of 37 fungal species colonizing highly irradiated, nutrient-poor Chernobyl reactor containment surfaces, relevant mainly as an astrobiology/extremophile analog rather than a direct origins-of-life study.
entry.content:
Abstract:
Extensive fungal growth has been detected on the walls and other building constructions in the inner parts of the Shelter of the damaged fourth Unit of the Chernobyl Nuclear Power Plant in 1997-98. The mycobiota comprised 37 species of 19 genera. Zygomycetes and ascomycetes were represented by one species each: Mucor plumbeus and Chaetomium globosum, [‚Ä¶] The post Fungi From Chernobyl: Mycobiota Of The Inner Regions Of The Containment Structures Of The Damaged Nuclear Reactor appeared first on Astrobiology .

Source Paper / DOIs Found:
  • [ScienceDirect] https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0953756208615026

entry.title: üü† Astrobiology ‚û§ Curiosity Mars Rover Views A Rock Made Of Sulfur At Snow Lake
entry.summary: Curiosity imaged and analyzed a sulfur-bearing Martian rock (‚ÄúSnow Lake‚Äù), a geochemical finding with indirect astrobiological relevance but limited direct connection to origins-of-life mechanisms.
entry.content:
Abstract:
NASA‚Äôs Curiosity captured this close-up image of a rock nicknamed ‚ÄúSnow Lake‚Äù on June 8, 2024, the 4,209th Martian day, or sol, of the mission. Nine days earlier, the rover had crushed a similar-looking rock and revealed crystalline textures ‚Äî and elemental sulfur ‚Äî inside. Astrobiology, Astrogeology, The post Curiosity Mars Rover Views A Rock Made Of Sulfur At Snow Lake appeared first on Astrobiology .

Source Paper:
No direct link found.

entry.title: üî¥ Astrobiology ‚û§ Considerations On The Process Of Target Selection For The Comet Interceptor Mission
entry.summary: Discusses how ESA‚Äôs Comet Interceptor will select a long-period comet target, a mission-planning topic with only indirect relevance to origins-of-life via comets as potential carriers of water and prebiotic organics.
entry.content:
Abstract:
Comet Interceptor is an ESA science mission with payload contributions from ESA Member States and with an international participation by JAXA. It is the first mission that is being designed, built, and potentially launched before its target is known. This approach will enable the spacecraft to perform the first mission to a Long Period Comet [‚Ä¶] The post Considerations On The Process Of Target Selection For The Comet Interceptor Mission appeared first on Astrobiology .
